Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Chance or necessity? Adaptive vs. non adaptive evolution in plant-frugivore interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the joint evolution of the olfactory ability and behavioral preferences of fruit-eating bats and the scents of the fruits that they eat. Plants have evolved an outstanding diversity of fruit characteristics to signal ripeness and, in turn, fruit-eaters have evolved specialized sensory abilities that allow them to locate ripe fruits. If and how bats have shaped the evolution of fruits traits, and how bat sensory abilities have evolved to detect fruit signals, however, remains poorly understood. Because the ecological interactions between fruiting plants and fruit-eating bats are crucial to the maintenance and regeneration of tropical ecosystems worldwide, this work will have important implications in the management of tropical forests. Results from this project will be incorporated into an exhibit at the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture and traveling study kits for elementary school students in Seattle and Costa Rica. The project will also provide training for a diverse group of undergraduates, graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, and a Costa Rican graduate student.

The project will focus on a relatively unexplored yet crucial aspect of plant-animal mutualisms: volatile chemical communication between plants and vertebrate frugivores. It will integrate advanced tools from analytical chemistry, molecular genetics, and behavioral ecology to collect unprecedented data on diet, fruit volatile molecules, bat olfactory genes and behavioral preferences for two ecologically important groups of tropical plants and animals (Piper plants and Carollia bats). This work will test whether mutualism has imposed selective pressures on plant and frugivore traits, or if their diversity is best explained by phylogeny. Novel comparative and experimental approaches will link the patterns of diversity in: (1) mutualism strength, (2) fruit scent chemical composition, (3) bat olfactory receptor subgenomes, and (4) bat scent preferences. By relating plant chemical signals to the olfactory subgenome and behavioral responses of frugivores, this research will jumpstart the integration of genomic and behavioral applications in evolutionary ecology, and enable future research on the functional chemical ecology of complex systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fruiting plants have evolved an outstanding diversity of fruit characteristics to signal ripeness to frugivores and, in turn, frugivores have evolved specialized sensory abilities that allow them to locate ripe fruits. The ecological interactions between fruiting plants and fruit-eating bats are crucial to the maintenance and regeneration of tropical ecosystems worldwide. If and how bats have shaped the evolution of fruit traits, and how bat sensory abilities have evolved to detect fruit signals, however, remains poorly understood. This award was the first to investigate the coevolution between fruit scents and the olfactory ability and behavioral preferences of fruit-eating bats. This work integrated advanced tools from analytical chemistry, molecular genetics, and behavioral ecology to collect unprecedented data on diet, fruit volatile molecules, bat olfactory genes and behavioral preferences for two ecologically important groups of tropical plants and animals, pepper plants (Piper) and short-tailed fruit bats (Carollia) in Costa Rica. 

 

This award generated the first comprehensive dataset showing the diversity in the chemical composition of ripe fruit and vegetation scent across 34 species of Piper, elucidated evolutionary relationships among Piper species coexisting in the study locality, corroborated and further expanded evidence that Carollia are primary consumers of Piper, and produced evidence that Carollia relies on fruit scent and specific chemical compounds to locate ripe fruit. The results from comparative analyses stemming from this award indicated that Piper ripe fruit scent differs among species and with respect to other plant organs. Evolutionary analyses further indicated that fruit scent, or its specific compounds, may have not evolved solely in response to bat consumption. Instead, fruit scent evolution appears to be driven by more complex processes. In parallel, this project pioneered the use of advanced community ecology methods for uncovering the traits correlated to differential Piper use, thereby illuminating the possible mechanisms underlying niche partitioning and Piper consumption among Carollia species. These technical advances can thus be more easily applied to answer complex questions surrounding ecological interactions.

 

Besides innovative ecological findings, this award generated new methods for uncovering and exploring the mammalian olfactory subgenome. Previous analyses had relied on whole-genome collections to compare olfactory subgenomes, which required large quantities of DNA and high-coverage to discern similar genes, and rendered these techniques not scalable in molecular ecology. Instead, this project developed the means to both obtain sufficient DNA from tiny quantities of tissue without whole-animal collections, generated whole subgenome scans at 3% of the cost per individual of whole-genome sequencing of the necessary resolution, and demonstrated the power of this method in comparisons with other techniques. 

 

By the closing date of this award, the team have produced 6 peer-reviewed and 5 non-peer-reviewed publications, 1 book, 4 book chapters, 3 Ph.D. Dissertations, and 41 presentations at national and international venues. One High School student, 22 undergraduates, 16 graduate students, and 2 postdoctoral scholars were trained in evolutionary ecology methods through this project. The research team worked with staff at the UW Burke Museum to integrate project results into the “Burke Bat Boxes”, which are traveling study kits that elementary school teachers can borrow to use in their classes. These have been used by over 51,000 elementary school students per year across Washington State. Award rationale, methods, and results were further disseminated to the general public via blog posts, presentations, and mini-exhibits at the Burke Museum.
